Sanskrit: vindáti "(he) finds", ávidat "found" vetti, vēdate, vidáti "(he) knows", perf. véda "I know"
Baltic: OPrus widatun "to see", Lith veidas "face"
Gothic: OHG giwahanen "mention" < PGerm *gawahnjan (denom. built on *wokʷ-no-)
Sanskrit: vákti, vívakti "(he) says", vāk "voice", vácas- "word"
Iranian: Av vač- "speak, say", vāxš "voice", vačah "word"
Slavic: OCS vikǫti "to call, to scream"
Celtic: OIr foccul "word", W gwaethl "fight"  < * wokʷ-tlo-m
Hittite: ḫuek-, ḫuk- to swear to"
Iranian: Av varəza- "work, activity", vərəzyeiti "(he) works"; NPers varz, barz "field work, husbandry"
Baltic: OPrus wargs "bad, evil, malicious, vicious", wargtwei "to torment oneself, to suffer", Lith vargas "the state of going through bad/unlucky events"
Tocharian: A wärk-, B wārk- "to shear"
Iranian: Av vaste, vaŋhaiti "(he) gets dressed"
Slavic: veshch "thing, cloth", veshchi "cloth items" Serbian veš "underwear"
Baltic: OPrus westi "corset", wesseli "wedding", Lith vestuvės "wedding", vesti "to lead"
English: wether "castrated male sheep" (< OE weþer),
Gothic: OHG widar "male sheep", MHG vert "last year" <- *per-ut-, ON fjorð "last year" <- *per-ut-
English: weigh (< OE wegan "carry"); way (< OE weġ); wain "wagon" (< OE wæġn)[ah]
Ancient Greek: Pamphylian wekʰétō "he should bring"; Cypriot éwekse "brought there"
Baltic: OPrus weztun "to ride", Lith vežti "to drive"
Celtic: OIr fēn, W gwain (type of wagon) < *weĝʰ-no-; W arwain "to lead"
Baltic: Lith výras "man"; OPrus wirs "man, husband"
Baltic: Lith lãpė "fox"; Lapskojis "fox's leg" (river name); vilpisÿs "wild cat"; Latv lapsa "fox"
Hittite: ulipzas (ú-li-ip-za-aš) "wolf";[59] Luwian ú-li-ip-ni-eš (nom. sg.), wa-li-ip-ni (dat.-loc. sg.) "fox"[60]
Iranian: Av perf. vaēδa "I know", vīdarǝ "they know"
Baltic: OPrus waistun "to know", Lith vaistas  "medicine", vyda "he sees, knows"
Celtic: OIr find, W gwn "(I) know"
Iranian: Av vaŋri "in spring"; OPers ϑūra-vāhara-
Baltic: OPrus wassara "spring", Lith vasara "summer", pavasaris "spring", vėsu "cool"
Celtic: OIr errach "spring"< *ferrach < *wesr-āko-; OW guiannuin "in spring" < *wes-n̥t-eino-
Sanskrit: udakám (loc. udán(i), pl. udá), udra "water"

wī́k̂m̥tiH₁.pron: w i k m t i h1

cognates: Sanskrit: yarhi - at which time / when
English: ye (< OE gē "you (nom. pl.)"), you (< OE ēow[23] "you (acc./dat. pl.)")
Ancient Greek: hum- "you (pl.)"; Aeol úmme "you (acc. pl.)" < *usme
Sanskrit: yūyám "you (nom. pl.)", yuṣmā́n "you (acc. pl.)" < y- + *usme + acc. -ān, encl. vaḥ "you (obl. pl.)"
Iranian: Av yūžǝm, yūš "you (nom. pl.)", yūšmat̃ "you (abl. pl.)", encl. vā̊ "you (obl. pl.)"
Baltic: Lith jũs "you (nom. pl.)", jũsų "yours (pl.)"; OPr iouson "yours (pl.)"
Celtic: OIr sī, sissi "you (nom. pl.)" < *sw-, uai-b "of you (pl.)" < *ō-swī, NIr far n- "your (pl.)"; W chwi "you (nom. pl.)" < *sw-
Tocharian: A yas, B yes "you (nom. pl.)"
Iranian: Av yākarǝ, NPers ǰigar, Pashto yī̆na "liver"
Slavic: Serbian jetra "liver", Serbian and Macedonian ikra "fish roe"
Baltic: OPrus jakna, Lat aknas "liver", Lith jeknos
Iranian: Av aspa-, OPers asa- "horse"; Ossetian yäfs "horse" < *yék̂wos NPers asp "horse"
Celtic: OIr ech; MW ebawl "horse" < PBryth *ep-ālos
Latin: archaic aser, sanguis "blood" (< possibly h₁sh₂-én- obl. stem + guen)
Baltic: Lat asins,  Ltg asnis (gen. ašņa) "blood"
Ancient Greek: oĩnos "one (on a die)", oĩ(w)os "alone"
Sanskrit: (ēka- < *oi-ko-; Mittani-Aryan aika-vartana "one turn (around a track)")[24]
Iranian: Av aēva-, OPers aiva- "one, only, alone"
Albanian: ? Gheg tânë, Tosk tërë "all" < PIE *tod-oino-; ??? një "one" < *ňân < PIE *eni-oino-[25]
Latin: gignō (gignere) "to produce" (OLat. genō); nā-scor (nāscī) "to be born" < *ĝn̥H₁-skṓ-r
Sanskrit: jánati "(he) gives birth", jajanti "they give birth"
Iranian: Av zīzǝnti, zīzanǝnti "they give birth"
Baltic: OPrus gamintun "to give birth", gimdyti "to give birth"
Celtic: OIr -gainethar "who is born" < *ĝn̥-ye-tro;[70] W geni "to be born"
Tocharian: AB kän- "to come to pass (of a wish), be realized"
Baltic: OPrus zirni "grain", Lith žirnis "pea", girna "millstone"
English: can (< OE cann "I know, he knows"), know (< OE cnāwan < *ĝnēH₃-yo-nom), Scot ken "to know" (< OE cennan "to cause to know" < PGerm *kann-jan)
Iranian: Av zanā-ṯ, zanąn < *ĝn̥-ne-H₃-ti; OPers a-dānā (impf.) "he knew" < *ĝn̥-ne-H₃-mi, xšnāsātiy (subj.) "he should know" < *ĝneH₃-sk̂e-eti
Baltic: OPrus zinatun "to recognize, know", Lith žinoti "to know
Celtic: OIr itar-gninim, asa-gninaim "I am wise"; W adnabod "(I) know"
Tocharian: A knā-, e.g. knānmaṃ "knowing" < *ĝneH₃-, kñas-äṣt "you have become acquainted" < *ĝnēH₃-s-
Ancient Greek: gónu (Hom gen. gounós < *gonwós)  "knee", pró-kʰnu "with outstretched knee" < *pró-gʰnu
Iranian: Av acc. žnūm, dat./abl. pl. žnubyō "knee", fra-šnu- "holding the knee forward"; Parth zānūk, NPers zānū "knee"
Tocharian: A kanweṃ, B keni "two knees"
Iranian: Av zāō "goose" (? not in Pokorny); Sogdian z’γ "kind of bird" , NPers ɣaz "goose"
Iranian: Av zyā̊ (acc. zyąm, gen. zimō) "winter"
Celtic: Gaul Giamonios "winter month";[ai][96][97] OIr gam "winter", gem-adaig "winter night"; OW gaem "winter"
Gothic: Goth kiusan "to prove, to test", kausjan "taste"; OHG kiosan "choose"
Albanian: desha "I loved"; dashje "liking, taste, preference" (< PAlb *dāusnja)
Ancient Greek: gómphos "bolt, nail"; gómphíos "molar tooth"
Sanskrit: jámbha- "tooth, tusk; set of teeth (pl.)"; jámbhya- "molar teeth"
Slavic: OCS zǫbŭ, Ukr zub, Pol ząb "tooth"
Baltic: Latv zùobs "tooth"; Lith žam̃bas "sharp edge"
